org.svvrl.goal.core.aut.opt

Class FairSimulation

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.svvrl.goal.core.aut.opt.FairSimulation

  • public class FairSimulation
extends java.lang.Object
    This class provides methods for the computation of fair simulation relations. The implementation follows [Kousha Etessami, Thomas Wilke, Rebecca A. Schuller: Fair Simulation Relations, Parity Games, and State Space Reduction for Büchi Automata. SIAM J. Comput. 34(5): 1159-1175 (2005)] for label-on-transition Büchi automata, and [Sankar Gurumurthy, Roderick Bloem, Fabio Somenzi: Fair Simulation Minimization. CAV 2002: 610-624] for label-on-state Büchi automata. Instead of small progress measure applied in the papers, we use the user-default parity game solver to solve fair simulation games.
    Author:
    Ming-Hsien Tsai

    • Nested Class Summary

      Nested Classes 
      Modifier and Type Class and Description
      static class  FairSimulation.CompoundState
      This class provides the compound state (s1, s2, a) owned by GamePlayer#P0 or (s1, s2) owned by GamePlayer#P1 where s1 is a state from an automaton A1, s2 is a state from an automaton A2, and a is a symbol in the alphabet.

      FairSimulation()

        public FairSimulation()

    • Method Detail

      • getFairSimulationGame

        public Game getFairSimulationGame(FSA aut)
        Returns a parity game used to compute the fair simulation relation of a Büchi automaton. All states of the returned game are FairSimulation.CompoundState. The returned game guarantees that a compound game state (s1, s2) owned by GamePlayer.P1 is in the winning region of GamePlayer.P0 if and only if s1 is fairly simulated by s2.
        Parameters:
        aut - a Büchi automaton
        Returns:
        a parity game used to compute the fair simulation relation of the Büchi automaton
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if aut is not a Büchi automaton

      • getFairSimulationGame

        public Game getFairSimulationGame(FSA aut1,
                                  FSA aut2)
        Returns a parity game used to compute the fair simulation relation of two Büchi automata. All states of the returned game are FairSimulation.CompoundState if the Büchi automata has labels on states while the states are FairSimulation.CompoundState if the Büchi automata has labels on transitions. The returned game guarantees that a compound game state (s1, s2) owned by GamePlayer.P1 is in the winning region of GamePlayer.P0 if and only if s1 in the first automaton is fairly simulated by s2 in the second automaton.
        Parameters:
        aut1 - a Büchi automaton
        aut2 - a Büchi automaton
        Returns:
        a parity game used to compute the fair simulation relation of the Büchi automata
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if aut1 or aut2 is not a Büchi automaton, the automata have different alphabet type, or the automata have different label position

      • getFairSimulationRelation

        public Relation<State> getFairSimulationRelation(FSA aut)
        Returns the fair simulation relation of a Büchi automaton. If (s1, s2) is in the returned relation, then s1 is fairly simulated by s2. Instead of the small progress measure solver used in the original papers, the default parity game solver will be used to solve the fair simulation game.
        Parameters:
        aut - a Büchi automaton
        Returns:
        the fair simulation relation of the Büchi automaton
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if aut is not a Büchi automaton

      • getFairSimulationRelation

        public Relation<State> getFairSimulationRelation(FSA aut,
                                                 GameSolver<MemorylessStrategy> solver)
                                          throws UnsupportedException
        Returns the fair simulation relation of a Büchi automaton. If (s1, s2) is in the returned relation, then s1 is fairly simulated by s2.
        Parameters:
        aut - a Büchi automaton
        solver - a parity game solver used to solve the fair simulation game
        Returns:
        the fair simulation relation of the Büchi automaton
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if aut is not a Büchi automaton
        UnsupportedException - if the specified game solver does not support parity games

      • getFairSimulationRelation

        public Relation<State> getFairSimulationRelation(FSA aut1,
                                                 FSA aut2)
        Returns the fair simulation relation of two Büchi automata. If (s1, s2) is in the returned relation, then s1 in the first automaton is fairly simulated by s2 in the second automaton. Instead of the small progress measure solver used in the original papers, the default parity game solver will be used to solve the fair simulation game.
        Parameters:
        aut1 - a Büchi automaton
        aut2 - a Büchi automaton
        Returns:
        the fair simulation relation of the Büchi automata
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if aut1 or aut2 is not a Büchi automaton, the automata have different alphabet type, or the automata have different label position

      • getFairSimulationRelation

        public Relation<State> getFairSimulationRelation(FSA aut1,
                                                 FSA aut2,
                                                 GameSolver<MemorylessStrategy> solver)
                                          throws UnsupportedException
        Returns the fair simulation relation of two Büchi automata. If (s1, s2) is in the returned relation, then s1 in the first automaton is fairly simulated by s2 in the second automaton.
        Parameters:
        aut1 - a Büchi automaton
        aut2 - a Büchi automaton
        solver - a parity game solver used to solve the fair simulation game
        Returns:
        the fair simulation relation of the Büchi automata
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if aut1 or aut2 is not a Büchi automaton, the automata have different alphabet type, or the automata have different label position
        UnsupportedException - if the specified game solver does not support parity games

      • isFairlySimulated

        public boolean isFairlySimulated(FSA aut1,
                                 FSA aut2)
        Returns true if the first specified Büchi automaton is fairly simulated by the second specified Büchi automaton. Instead of the small progress measure solver used in the original papers, the default parity game solver will be used to solve the fair simulation game.
        Parameters:
        aut1 - a Büchi automaton
        aut2 - a Büchi automaton
        Returns:
        true if aut1 is fairly simulated by aut2
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if aut1 or aut2 is not a Büchi automaton, the automata have different alphabet type, or the automata have different label position

      • isFairlySimulated

        public boolean isFairlySimulated(FSA aut1,
                                 FSA aut2,
                                 GameSolver<MemorylessStrategy> solver)
                          throws UnsupportedException
        Returns true if the first specified Büchi automaton is fairly simulated by the second specified Büchi automaton.
        Parameters:
        aut1 - a Büchi automaton
        aut2 - a Büchi automaton
        solver - a parity game solver used to solve the fair simulation game
        Returns:
        true if aut1 is fairly simulated by aut2
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if aut1 or aut2 is not a Büchi automaton, the automata have different alphabet type, or the automata have different label position
        UnsupportedException - if the specified game solver does not support parity games
